# Question

Write a function `wrap_string`. It iterates over words and it will add a new line each time a maximum `text_width::Int=10` would be exceeded. Provide an example

Here is a Julia function named `wrap_string` that breaks a given string into lines, ensuring that each line does not exceed a specified maximum width. If no width is specified, it defaults to 10 characters. The function handles the input string word by word to avoid breaking words across lines unless a single word exceeds the maximum width.

```julia
function wrap_string(input_string::String, text_width::Int=10)
    words = split(input_string)
    current_line_length = 0
    result = ""

    for word in words
        word_length = length(word)
        if current_line_length + word_length > text_width
            if current_line_length > 0
                result *= "\n"
            end
            current_line_length = 0
        end
        if current_line_length > 0
            result *= " "
            current_line_length += 1
        end
        result *= word
        current_line_length += word_length
    end

    return result
end

# Example usage:
text = "Julia is a high-level, high-performance dynamic programming language."
wrapped_text = wrap_string(text)
println(wrapped_text)
```

In this example, if you run the function `wrap_string` with the provided string, it will print the string wrapped to a maximum width of 10 characters per line, taking care not to split individual words across lines. Adjust the `text_width` parameter to change the maximum line width as needed.
